channel.title: English (Grammar) on Pandaqi Tutorials
channel.description: Recent content in English (Grammar) on Pandaqi Tutorials

item.title: Introduction
item.description: English has become the language of the world. Learning it will help you communicate clearly with basically anyone. It’s not just a useful skill, it’s almost an essential skill.

item.title: Sentences: Subject & Verb
item.description: Let’s start with the absolute basics. Grammar is all about creating sentences with meaning, by putting words in the right order.

item.title: Sentences: Object
item.description: Where are we now? We know about sentences. We know how to start and end one. We know they have a verb (what’s happening) and a subject (who or what is making that happen).

item.title: Sentences: Modifiers & Clauses
item.description: Now you can form short, basic sentences. Determine the action, who does it, who is the target of the action, and who might participate.

item.title: Nouns: Roles & Gender
item.description: Nouns are the basic building blocks of every language, together with verbs. The subject of a sentence will always be a noun, just like the object.

item.title: Nouns: Articles
item.description: Earlier, I talked about placing “the” in front of English words. I’ve quietly used it in all examples so far.

item.title: Nouns: Counting
item.description: We’ve learned how to write nouns when there’s one of them, or when there’s multiple of them. (And what article to put in front of it.

item.title: Nouns: Possessive
item.description: A noun can belong to someone or something. In other words, it’s the possession of that other person.

item.title: Pronouns
item.description: Pronouns are a subset of nouns. This means they are still nouns. But they are part of a special group that follows the same rules.

item.title: Indefinite Pronouns
item.description: Throughout this course, I’m trying to teach you grammar, but also the subtleties of the English language. The highlights and unique ideas.

item.title: Prepositions
item.description: This is the last chapter before you learn about verbs. Prepositions often go unnoticed, but are equally important as the other elements of grammar.

item.title: Verbs: the basics
item.description: You’ve spent ten chapters learning the basics of English sentences and nouns. Hopefully you agree that was time well spent.

item.title: Verbs: helpers
item.description: Last chapter you learned about verbs. How they match their subject and the timing of the sentence. And how easy it is to use the infinitive to create the simple present: an action that happens now.

item.title: Verbs: contractions
item.description: Where are we now? You know the present tense and how to modify it. You know common verbs: to be, to do and to have.

item.title: Verbs: simple tense
item.description: Many courses or textbooks on English group verbs by time: past, present and future. I don’t like that approach.

item.title: Verbs: continuous tense
item.description: The continuous tense is named quite well. It describes an action that is continuing to happen. The simple tense described an action in a general way.

item.title: Verbs: perfect tense
item.description: We have seen two tenses so far. Those are the building blocks of English: Simple tense: for general truths or predictions about present, past and future Continuous tense: for actual specific actions happening at a clear point in time (present, past or future) What’s missing?

item.title: Verbs: conditional tense
item.description: These tenses are less common. Some of them are rare in spoken English and mostly reserved for written text.

item.title: Verbs: gerund
item.description: The gerund is nothing more than the continous form we’ve been using all this time. (Walking, talking, eating, etcetera.

item.title: Verbs: present participle
item.description: The present participle is another word that simply uses the continuous form you already know. (Walking, talking, eating, speaking, …)

item.title: Verbs: infinitives
item.description: I mentioned the infinitive right at the start of the verb chapters. It’s how you find verbs in the dictionary.

item.title: Verbs: passive voice
item.description: All sentences, examples, and tutorials so far have been active voice. I recommend using that whenever you can. Because it’s shorter, simpler and more direct.

item.title: Adjectives
item.description: Well done! You have learned all about the two basic blocks of English language: nouns and verbs. You should be able to read and write any basic sentence—with any time or intention.

item.title: Adverbs
item.description: Adverbs are the wildcard of any language. They can be formed out of anything and applied to nearly everything.

item.title: Determiners
item.description: You’ve mastered the basics of English language … almost. Only two more chapters. This one will talk about the many simple but crucial words for making everything work.

item.title: Cheat Sheet
item.description: Use the image below to quickly remind yourself of the basic grammar rules. In case you are in doubt or forgot something.

item.title: Conjunctions & Compounds
item.description: This course taught you all the small, individual pieces that make up a language. You’ve also seen ways to combine and modify them: using prepositions, adverbs, pronouns.

item.title: Clock & Dates
item.description: Denoting time is one of the oldest functions of a language. You know what that means by now: irregularity.

item.title: Common Mistakes
item.description: In this course, I’ve often left remarks about the best way to write things. I find this important. Language is about communication, so let’s see how to improve that communication as much as possible.
